verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:1
verses.text: The Letter of Anastasius,  Bishop of the Church of Rome to John Bishop of Jerusalem Concerning the Character of Rufinus.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:2
verses.text: The letter of Anastasius to John of Jerusalem was written in the year 401; it is spoken of in Jerome's Apol.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:3
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:5
verses.text: 21, which was written in the first half of 402, as "the letter of last year".

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:6
verses.text: Jerome intimates in the same passage that it was only one of several letters of the same character which Anastasius wrote to the East.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:7
verses.text: Rufinus had not seen it, and refused to believe its genuineness.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:8
verses.text: But there seems to be no reason for doubting this.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:9
verses.text: Anastasius had, at the earnest request of Theophilus of Alexandria, formally condemned Origenism.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:10
verses.text: And Rufinus' translations of Origen's Περὶ ᾽Αρχῶν and of Pamphilus' Vindication of Origen, and his own book on the Falsification of Origen's works were taken at Rome as a defence of Origenism generally.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:11
verses.text: Rufinus, however, appealed continually, and especially in his Apology to Anastasius, to the church of Jerusalem, where he had been ordained.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:12
verses.text: "My faith," he says, "is that which is preached at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:13
verses.text: Anastasius, therefore, in condemning Origen would be understood as condemning Rufinus, and might also seem to condemn his Bishop John of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:14
verses.text: This will account for the fulsome praises with which the letter opens.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:15
verses.text: John, moreover, had written "to consult" Anastasius about Rufinus, which probably implies some action in Rufinus' interest; but the fact that Jerome knew the contents of the letter and Rufinus did not seems to show that Bishop John had become more friendly with Jerome and less so with Rufinus.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:17
verses.text: The kind words of approval that you have addressed, my dear Bishop, to your brother Bishop, is a fresh mark of your long tried affection.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:18
verses.text: It is a high commendation which you confer upon me, a most lavish recognition of my services.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:19
verses.text: I thank you for this proof of your love; and, following you at a distance in my littleness, I bring the tribute of my words to honour the splendour of your holiness and those virtues which the Lord has conferred upon you.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:20
verses.text: You excel all others so far, the splendour of your praise shines forth so conspicuously, that no words which I can use can equal your deserts.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:21
verses.text: Yet your glory excites in me such admiration that I cannot turn away from the attempt to describe it, even though I can never do so adequately.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:22
verses.text: And, first, the praise which you have bestowed on me out of the serene heaven of your great spirit forms part of your own glory: for it is the majesty of your episcopate, shining forth like the sun upon the opposite quarter of the world, which has reflected its own brightness upon us.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:23
verses.text: And you give me your friendship unreservedly; you do not weigh me in the balance of criticism.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:24
verses.text: If it is right for you to praise me, must not your praise be echoed back to you? I beg you therefore, for your own sake no less than mine, that you will not praise me any more to my face.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 1:25
verses.text: I ask this for two reasons: if the praise is undeserved it must excite in your brother-bishop a sense of pain; if it is true, it must make him blush.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 2:2
verses.text: Let me come to the subject of your letter.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 2:3
verses.text: Rufinus, about whom you have done me the honour to ask my advice, must bring his conscience to the bar of the divine majesty.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 2:4
verses.text: It is for him to see how he can approve himself to God as maintaining his true allegiance to him.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 3:2
verses.text: As for Origen, whose writings he has translated into our language, I have neither formerly known, nor do I now seek to know either who he was or what expression he may have given to his thought.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 3:3
verses.text: But as to the feeling left by this matter on my own mind I should be glad to speak with your holiness for a moment.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 3:4
verses.text: The impression which I have received is this,—and it has been brought out clearly by the reading of parts of Origen's works by the people of our City, and by the sort of mist of blindness which it threw over them,—that his object was to disintegrate our faith, which is that of the Apostles, and has been confirmed by the traditions of the fathers, by leading us into tortuous paths.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 4:2
verses.text: I want to know what is the meaning of the translation of this work into the Roman tongue.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 4:3
verses.text: If the translator intends by it to put the author in the wrong, and to denounce to the world his execrable deeds, well and good.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 4:4
verses.text: In that case he will expose to well-merited hatred one who has long laboured under the adverse weight of public opinion.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 4:5
verses.text: But if by translating all these evil things he means to give his assent to them, and in that sense gives them to the world to read, then the edifice which he has reared at the expense of so much labour serves for nothing else than to make the guilt the act of his own will, and to give the sanction of his unlooked for support to the overthrow of all that is of prime importance in the true faith as held by Catholic Christians from the time of the Apostles till now.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:2
verses.text: Far be such teaching from the catholic system of the Church of Rome.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:3
verses.text: It can never by any possibility come to pass that we should accept as reasonable things which we condemn as matters of law and right.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:4
verses.text: We have, therefore, the assurance that Christ our God, whose providence reaches over the whole world, bestows his approval on us when we say that it is wholly impossible for us to admit doctrines which defile the church, which subvert its well tried moral system, which offend the ears of all who are witnesses of our doings and lay the ground for strife and anger and dissensions.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:5
verses.text: This was the motive which led me to write my letter to Venerius our brother in the Episcopate, the character of which, written as it was in my weakness but with great care and diligence, you will realize by what I now subjoin: "Whence, then, he who translated the work has gained and preserves this assurance of innocence I am not greatly troubled to know: it fills me with no vain alarm.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:6
verses.text: I certainly shall omit nothing which may enable me to guard the faith of the Gospel amongst my own people, and to warn, as far as in me lies, those who form part of my body, in whatever part of the world they live, not to allow any translation of profane authors to creep in and spring up amongst them, which will seek to unsettle the mind of devout men by spreading its own darkness among them.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:7
verses.text: Moreover, I cannot pass over in silence an event which has given me great pleasure, the decree issued by our Emperors, by which every one who serves God is warned against the reading of Origen, and all who are convicted of reading his impious works are condemned by the imperial judgment".

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 5:8
verses.text: In these words my formal sentence was pronounced.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 6:2
verses.text: You are troubled by the complaint which people make as to our treatment of Rufinus, so that you pursue certain persons with vague suspicions.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 6:3
verses.text: But I will meet this feeling of yours with an instance taken from holy writ, namely, where it is said: "Man seeth not as God seeth; for God looketh upon the heart, but man upon the countenance".

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 6:4
verses.text: Therefore, my dearly beloved brother, put away all your prejudice.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 6:5
verses.text: Weigh the conduct of Rufinus in your own unbiassed judgment; ask yourself whether he has not translated Origen's words into Latin and approved them, and whether a man who gives his encouragement to vicious acts committed by another differs at all from the guilty party.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 6:6
verses.text: In any case I beg you to be assured of this, that he is so completely separate from all part or lot with us, that I neither know nor wish to know either what he is doing or where he is living.

verses.name: Rufinus: Letter of Anastasius 6:7
verses.text: I have only to add that it is for him to consider where he may obtain absolution.
